turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Can you get some sworn statements?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: That's gonna be tough.  Nobody's talking.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I think we should have him in for a little talk.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: That's fine, Numa, but what about all the people who aren't writing letters.  They're sitting home reading all these lies.  I just heard NBC crew's in town to do a "White Paper" - not on the Kennedy killing, but on us.  One of their top guys, Harry Stoner, is talking to everybody he can find about you, boss...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh Jesus, Stoner!... Why doesn't he call me?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Those bastards!  That's proof enough right there of what we're up against. The whole goddamn Federal Government, Bill!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, they offered you the carrot, and you turned it down... you know what's coming next, don't you, boss?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Found another note, same thing, no name, no signature.  "When you receive this, I will be quite dead, so no answer will be possible.  I offered you love.  All I got in return in the end was a kick in the teeth."

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Jesus, they must've been hard pressed to come up with that one.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: All right, all right.  Break it up.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Where you going, boss?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't know, Bill, I just don't know.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I don't buy it, chief - why would the FBI cover it up?  You're talking the whole FBI here.  A telex that disappears from every single FBI office in the country?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: There's a word - orders.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Shaw's our toehold, Bill.  I don't know exactly what he is, where he fits, and I don't care.  I do know he's lying through his teeth and I'm not gonna let go of him!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: So for those reasons, you're going to trial against Clay Shaw, chief? Well, you're gonna lose!  We should be investigating all our Mafia leads here in New Orleans - Carlos Marcello, Santos Trafficante - I can buy that a hell of a lot easier than the Government.  Ruby's all Mob, knows Oswald, sets him up.  Hoffa - Trafficante - Marcello, they hire some guns and they do Kennedy and maybe the Government doesn't want to open up a whole can o'worms there because it used the Mob to get to Castro.  Y'know, Castro being assassinated sounds pretty wild to John Q.  Citizen.  So they close the book on J.F.K.  It makes sense to me.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't doubt their involvement, Bill, but at a low level.  Could the Mob change the parade route, Bill, or eliminate the protection for the President?  Could the Mob send Oswald to Russia and get him back?  Could the Mob get the FBI, the CIA, and the Dallas Police to make a mess of the investigation?  Could the Mob appoint the Warren Commission to cover it up?  Could the Mob wreck the autopsy?  Could the Mob influence the national media to go to sleep? And since when has the Mob used anything but .38's for hits, up close? The Mob wouldn't have the guts or the power for something of this magnitude.  Assassins need payrolls, orders, times, schedules.  This was a military-style ambush from start to finish... a coup d'etat with Lyndon Johnson waiting in the wings.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Oh, now you're saying Lyndon Johnson was involved?  The President of the United States?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I know this, Bill - Lyndon Johnson got $1 billion for his Texas friends, Brown and Root, to dredge Cam Ranh Bay for the military in Vietnam. That's just for openers.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Boss, are you calling the President a murderer?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: If I'm so far from the truth, why is the FBI bugging our offices?  Why are our witnesses being bought off and murdered?  Why are Federal agencies blocking our extraditions and subpoenas when we were never blocked before?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Maybe 'cause there's some rogue element in the Government!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: With a full-blown conspiracy to cover it up?  Y'ever read your Shakespeare, Bill?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Julius Caesar:  "Brutus and Cassius, they too are honorable men."  Who killed Caesar?  Twenty, twenty-five Senators.  All it takes is one Judas, Bill - a few people, on the inside, Pentagon, CIA...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: This is Louisiana, chief.  How the hell do you know who your daddy is? 'Cause your momma told you so... You're way out there taking a crap in the wind, boss, and I for one ain't going along on this one.  Jim sighs, saddened.  Bill was one of his best men.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What's it look like, Nick?

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: I don't see any violence, Jim.  Heart attack, maybe an aneurysm.  Looks like natural causes.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Nick, what would happen if a man suffering from hypertension were to take an entire bottle of Proloid?

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: He'd die pretty quick, either a heart storm or a ruptured blood vessel in the brain.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Can you ascertain if there's Proloid in his system?

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: Not in a routine autopsy, but if we looked at the spinal fluid, there might be a high level of iodine, but it's difficult to know.  Whatcha thinkin', Jim?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, it doesn't make sense, Nick - he was afraid of dying, then he kills himself in a way that leaves no trace, but he leaves two unsigned suicide notes.

turns.speaker: CORONER
turns.text: If it's a suicide, I seen weirder, Jim.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: Mr. Goldberg, you claim you met David Ferrie and Clay Shaw while on a vacation here from your accounting business in New York, you had drinks and, under the influence discussed killing Kennedy, is that not so?

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: I did.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: Well, I wanted to make sure she's the same girl I sent.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: I see... and why are you experiencing this paranoia?

turns.speaker: GOLDBERG
turns.text: Well, you see, I've been subject to hypnosis and psychological warfare ever since 1948, when I was in Korea...

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: ...Oswald?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No, I did not.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: ...ever called Dean Andrews?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No, I did not.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: ...and have you ever met David Ferrie?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No, I would not even know what he looked like except for the pictures I've been shown.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: ...did you ever use the alias Clay Bertrand?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No, I did not.

turns.speaker: DYMOND
turns.text: Thank you... Mr. Shaw.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: You know damn well who it is.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Dave?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Yeah, you got it.  Since you're the only straight shooter in that fuckin' office, I'd like an answer from you. Did you plant it?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Dave, do you think we're out of our minds?  The whole building's been a zoo since that broke.  We can't get a thing done.  Reporters crawling everywhere.  You think we want that?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Somebody planted that fucking story! And somebody tipped off the press I'm one of Garrison's fucking suspects.  I can't go home. I'm out on the street.  The maggots are everywhere!  Do you know what you've done to me?  It's all over the national news now.  You know what you've done to me?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Calm down, Dave, what?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I'm a dead man!  From here on, believe me, I'm a dead man.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: What are you talking about, Dave? You weren't mentioned in the story. Don't jump to conclusions.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: You think your investigation's been all that secret?  You know, when you talk to people, they talk to other people.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: What did they...

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: You still questioning any Cubans?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Dave, you know that's where this road leads.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: It leads farther than that.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Dave, just calm down.  Meet me in the lobby of the Fontainbleau in 20 minutes.  I'll have a suite reserved for you under an assumed name.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: The Fontainbleau?  20 minutes?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Yeah.  Come on, Dave, come on our side.  I guarantee you the boss'll protect you...  Dave?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: ...give me protection?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Yeah!  He'd kill for you Dave.  He likes you.  Your mind.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I got no place to sleep.  I'll meet you in 20 minutes.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I'm caught in the middle.  They're after me.  It's almost over.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Listen, Dave, why don't we order some room service, have a bite, relax. I'll stay as long as you want.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I don't know who to trust anymore. Yeah, sure I could use a pot of hot coffee and a few packs of Camels. You got anything new in the investigation?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Dave, I always play square.  No bugs. I'd love you to go on the record, but I"m in no hurry.  Whenever you're ready.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I don't have much time.  They don't even need bugs anymore.  They got these fuckin' satellite waves.  They put a bug in a friend of mine when he was born, right up his nostrils, subcutaneous, between his eyes.  He was one of those products of a crossbreading experiment.  A Nazi rocket scientist father and a Commie spy mother.  You'd never believe half the shit the Agency does.  I'm so fuckin' tired.  Haven't slept since that shit article came out. Why'd you guys have to go and get me involved with this?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Did we involve you, Dave, or did Clay Shaw?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: That cocksuckin' faggot!  He's got me by the balls.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Photographs - compromising stuff. And he'll use 'em.  The Agency plays for keeps...  I knew Oswald.  He was in my Civil Air Patrol unit.  I taught him everything.  A "wanna be," y'know, nobody really liked him cause he was a snitch.  I treated him good.  He'd talk about his kid, y'know, really wanted her to grow up with a chance, but... He got a raw deal.  The Agency fucked him.  Just like they're gonna fuck me.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: What about the mob, Dave?  How do they figure in this?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: They're Agency, too.  Don't you get it?  CIA and Mafia together.  Trying to whack out the Beard.  Mutual interests.  They been doing it for years.  There's more to this than you dream.  FBI fucking hates the CIA.  Navy Intelligence got something to do with it too.  Check out "Alan Pope" in Miami.  Jack Youngblood. Bill Harvey.  Colonel Roselli.  The shooter, I hear, was a Dallas cop - the bagman at Ruby's club.  I heard he shot his own partner.  Got that? Check out the rich fucks in Dallas. H.L. Hunt.  He's dirty.  That's all I know.  But the Agency always runs the show.  Check out something called "Mongoose"  Operation Mongoose. Government, Pentagon stuff, they're in charge, but who the fuck pulls whose chain who the fuck knows, fun 'n' games man - check out Southeast Asia - that's the next big number - the heroin trail.  "Oh, what a deadly web we weave when we practice to deceive."

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Come in, Dave.  Have a seat, make yourself comfortable.  Coffee?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Do you remember me, Mr. Garrison?  I met you on Carondolet Street right after your election.  I congratulated you, remember?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: How could I forget?  You make quite a first impression.  Sharon, could you please bring us some coffee?  I've heard over the years you're quite a first-rate pilot, Dave. Legend has it you can get in and out of any field, no matter how small...  I'm a bit of a pilot myself, you know.  Flew grasshoppers for the field artillery in the war.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Do you mind if I smoke, Mr. Garrison?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: How could I?  Dave, as you know, President Kennedy was assassinated on Friday.  A man named Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested as a suspect and then was murdered yesterday by a man named Jack Ruby.  We've heard reports that Oswald spent the summer in New Orleans and we've been advised you knew Oswald pretty well.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: That's not true.  I never met anybody named Oswald.  Anybody who told you that has to be crazy.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you are aware, he served in your Civil Air Patrol unit when he was a teenager.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: No... if he did, I don't remember him.  There were lots of kids in and out... y'know.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm sure you've seen this.  Perhaps you knew this man under another name?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: No, I never saw him before in my life.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well that must've been mistaken information we got.  Thanks for straightening it out for us.  There is one other matter that's come up, Dave.  We were told you took a trip to Texas shortly after the assassination of Friday.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Yeah, now that's true.  I drove to Houston.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What was so appealing about Houston?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I hadn't been there ice skating in many years, and I had a couple of young friends with me, and we decided we wanted to go ice skating.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Dave, may I ask why the urge to go ice skating in Texas happened to strike you during one of the most violent thunderstorms in recent memory?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Oh, it was just a spur of the moment thing...  the storm wasn't that bad.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I see.  And where did you drive?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: We went straight to Houston, and then Saturday night we drove to Galveston and stayed over there.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why Galveston?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: No particular reason.  Just to go somewhere.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And then Sunday?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: In the morning we went goose hunting. Then headed home, but I dropped the boys off to see some relatives and I stayed in Hammond.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Did you bag any geese on this trip?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: I believe the boys got a couple.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But the boys told us they didn't get any.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Oh yes, well, come to think of it, they're right.  We got to where the geese were and there were thousands of them.  But you couldn't approach them.  They were a wise bunch of birds.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Your young friends also told us you had no weapons in the car.  Dave, isn't it a bit difficult to hunt for geese without a shotgun?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Yes, now I remember, Mr. Garrison. I'm sorry, I got confused.  We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns.  Stupid, right?  So of course we didn't get any geese.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I see.  Dave thank you for your time.  I'm sorry it has to end inconveniently for you, but I'm going to have you detained for further questioning by the FBI.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Why?  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Dave, I find your story simply not believable.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Leon's in a bad mood, don't get excited, he's all right.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Would you say this "Leon" was actually Lee Harvey Oswald?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You mean about the Cubans getting trained north of the lake?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Oh, you got that?  Banister's pet project.  Getting paid by the government to work against the government.  Beautiful.  What a mind he had, what a guy, Guy.  He had all those files.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Who was paying you, Dave?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: You think I was a getaway pilot for the assassination, don't you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't know.  Were you?  Who you scared of, Dave?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Everybody!  The Agency.  The Mob. The Cubans.  Yeah, follow the Cubans. Check them out.  Here, in Dallas, Miami.  Check out a guy named Eladio del Valle.  My paymaster when I flew missions into Cuba - he's somewhere in Miami.  You're on the right track.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Let me get this straight, now.  Clay Shaw is blackmailing you?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Fuckin' A.  How do you think the Agency gets people to do their bullshit?  Fuck knows what they got on Oswald!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Was it the same Oswald, Dave, that was in Dallas, or was it an impersonator.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Same one.  I didn't know no impersonator.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Did you take a good look at the TV when they had Oswald?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Black, black - just give it to me.  Shit.  I'm so exhausted.  My neck is killing me.  I've got cancer.  Had it for years.  I been working with mice, y'know, trying to come up with a cure.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Dave, can I just ask you this directly?  Did you ever work for the CIA?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: You make it sound like some remote fuckin' experience in ancient history. Man, you never leave the Agency. Once they got you, you're in for life.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And Shaw?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Shaw's an "untouchable", man - highest clearance.  Shaw, Oswald, the Cubans - all Agency.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What about Ruby?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Jack?  Jack was a pimp.  A bagman in Dallas for the Mob.  He used to run guns to Castro when he was still on our side.  Check out Jack Youngblood. Shit - we almost had Castro.  Then we tried to whack him.  Everybody's flipping sides all the time.  It's fun 'n' games, man fun 'n' games.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Then who killed the President?

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Oh man, why don't you stop.  This is too fuckin' big for you!  Who did Kennedy?  It's a mystery wrapped in a riddle inside an enigma.  Even the shooters don't fuckin' know!  Don't you get it yet?  I can't be talking like this.  They're gonna kill me. I'm gonna die!  I don't know what happened.  All I wanted in the world was to be a Catholic priest - live in a monastery, study ancient Latin manuscripts, pray, serve God.  But I had this one terrible, fatal weakness.  They defrocked me.  And then I started to lose everything.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Shit!  Forgot to glue this fuckin' rug today.  You know, at one time I even had a full head of hair like everyone else.  And then I lost that. That fuckin' Clay Shaw.  I hate the bastard.  All I got left is in his rotten, bloody hands.  He tipped the newspapers - I know it.  That's how the Agency works.  They use people, chew them up, spit 'em out.  Now it's my turn.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Dave, it's going to be okay.  Just talk to us on the record and we'll protect you.  I guarantee it.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: They'll get to you, too - they'll destroy you... They're untouchable, man...  I'm so fucking exhausted I can't see straight.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Get some rest, Dave, and you'll feel better in the morning.  We'll talk then.

turns.speaker: FERRIE
turns.text: Yeah, yeah.  But leave me alone for awhile.  I got to make some calls.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Colonel Finck, are you saying someone told you not to dissect the neck?

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: I was told that the family wanted examination of the head.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: As a pathologist it was your obligation to explore all possible causes of death, was it not?

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: I had the cause of death.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Your Honor, I would ask you to direct the witness to answer my question. Why did Colonel Finck not dissect the track of the bullet wound in the neck?

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: Well I heard Dr. Humes stating that - he said...

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: I don't remember his name.  You must understand it was quite crowded, and when you are called in circumstances like that to look at the wound of the President who is dead, you don't look around too much to ask people for their names and who they are.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you were a qualified pathologist. Was this Army general a qualified pathologist?

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you took his orders.  He was directing the autopsy.

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: No, because there were others.  There were admirals.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: There were admirals.

turns.speaker: FINCK
turns.text: Oh yes, there were admirals - and when you are a lieutenant colonel in the Army you just follow orders, and at the end of the autopsy we were specifically told - as I recall it was Admiral Kenney, the Surgeon General of the Navy - we were specifically told not to discuss the case.

turns.speaker: JUDGE HAGGERTY
turns.text: I'm going to have to ask the jury to leave the courtroom.

turns.speaker: GARRISON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GARRISON
turns.text: Jesus, Ed, from time immemorial it's been standard booking procedure to ask an alias.  You know that.  There's no constitutional requirement that says a lawyer has to be present for routine questions.

turns.speaker: JUDGE HAGGERTY
turns.text: I call'em as I see'em, Jim.  I'm ruling it inadmissible.

turns.speaker: GARRISON
turns.text: That's our case!

turns.speaker: JUDGE HAGGERTY
turns.text: If that's your case, you didn't have a case.  I wouldn't believe whatever Habighorst said, anyway.

turns.speaker: GARRISON
turns.text: I can't believe you're saying this in the courtroom.

turns.speaker: JUDGE HAGGERTY
turns.text: Well, I am saying it.  Bring in the jury.

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: Daddy said it was all right if I was real quiet.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sure it is.  Freckle Face, if I ever handled a minor felon like that, it'd be all over the papers.  I'd catch hell.  And this is the alleged murderer of the President?

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: Dad, look what I drew.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's something, Jasper.  What is it?

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: A rhinoceros.  Can I stay up another hour?

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: Daddy!  Where have you been?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hi, Freckle Face.

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: Are we going away, Daddy?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, it looks like it, Jasper.

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: Because of Kennedy?  Are the same people gonna kill us, Daddy?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, Jasper, nobody's gonna kill us.

turns.speaker: JASPER
turns.text: I'm scared.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: There's nothing wrong with feeling a little scared, Jasper, Virginia. Telling the truth can be a scary thing.  It scared President Kennedy, but he was a brave man.  If you let yourself be too scared, then you let the bad guys take over the country, don't you - and then everybody gets scared.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: He asked me why I thought I was in danger and I said:

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: Well if they can kill the President, they can certainly get me.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: That doesn't make sense, Mrs. Hill. We have the man that killed the President.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: No, you don't!

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: He kept trying to get me to change my story about the shots.  He was getting hot under the collar, and telling the woman not to write when he wanted.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: Look, do you want the truth, or just what you want me to say?

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: I want the truth.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: The truth is that I heard between four and six shots.  I'm not going to lie for you.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: ...you heard echoes.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: No.  I had guns all my life.  I used to go turtle shooting.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: I realize you're under a great deal of stress .. it's clouded your judgement.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: So off the record, he starts talking about my family, and even mentioned my marriage was in trouble like I didn't know it or something.  He got angrier and angrier and then:

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Look, we can put you in a mental institution.  We can make you look crazier'n Marguerite Oswald, and everybody knows how crazy she is.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: I knew something was crooked as a dog's hind leg, 'cause no one who is just taking a deposition gets that involved and angry... sure enough, when I finally read my testimony as published by the Warren Commission, it was a fabrication from start to finish.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: These new people never identified themselves.  They musta been watching the whole thing 'cause they knew everything Mary and me had been doing that day.  I guess I wasn't too hard to find - wearing that red raincoat.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: How many shots you say you heard?

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: Four to six.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: That's impossible.  You heard echoes ...echoes.  We have three bullets and three shots which came from the Book Depository and that's all we're willing to say.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: ...which is strange 'cause this is less than 20 minutes after the assassination.

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: No, I saw a guy shooting from over there.  He was behind that fence. What are you going to do about it?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: We have that taken care of.  You only heard three shots and you are not to talk to anyone about this. No one, you hear?

turns.speaker: JEAN HILL
turns.text: I was scared.  It was all kinda queer, but it sure felt like two and two was coming up three... and then they took Mary's five snapshots from me, sent them to Washington, and when they returned them weeks later, two of them had the backgrounds mutilated... The only one we saved was in Mary's camera.  I didn't want to go to Washington when the Warren Commission subpoenaed me... so the lawyer come down here and interviewed me at Parkland Hospital.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: If we go to him our investigation'll hit the front pages by sunrise. Blow up right in our face.  Ruby was just given a new trial.  If he has something to say, it'll be there. Susie, what did you find out on Oswald?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Negative on his tax records. Classified.  First time I know a D.A. can't get a tax record.  I put together a list of all the CIA files on Oswald that were part of the Warren Report and asked for them.  There are about 1200 documents...  Oswald in the USSR, in Mexico City, Oswald and the U2, a CIA 201 personnel file, a memo from the Director on Oswald, travel and activities - can't get one of them.  All classified as secret on the grounds of national security.  It's real strange.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Finally they shuttle him to a radio factory in Minks where he lives as high on the hog as he ever has - he's given 5,000 rubles, a roomy apartment with a balcony, has affairs with local girls.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Makes sense - he's a spokesman.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: But he never writes, speaks, or does any propaganda for the Russians.  He meets Marina, whose uncle is a colonel in Soviet intelligence, at a trade union dance; she thinks he's Russian the way he speaks, six weeks later they marry, have a daughter.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Don't get sidetracked!  How does he get back to the States?  That's the point.  Does he have any problems?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: None!  The State Department issues him a new passport in 48 hours and loans him the money to travel.  He's never investigated or charged by the Navy for revealing classified information or, as far as we know, debriefed by the CIA.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: This is a man whose secrets cause us to change our radar patterns in the Pacific!  He should've been prosecuted as a traitor!

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The FBI finally gets around to talking to him in Dallas and runs a file on him as a miscreant Communist type.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But who meets him when he gets off the boat in New York in June '62?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Spas T. Raikin, a leading member of an anti-Communist group.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And Marina?  Does she have a problem getting out?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: None either.  It's bizarre.  It's next to impossible to get Russian sweethearts out.  Nor does Lee have any problem getting a new passport when he wants to go to Cuba and Russia in '63.  A man who has defected once already.  It's crazy.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Dammit, it doesn't add up!  Ordinary people get blacklisted for leftist affiliations!  The State Department did everything short of dispatching a destroyer to Minks to insure Oswald's return.  Only intelligence people can come and go like that.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The next thing we know he's living in Dallas/Ft. Worth in October '62 working 6 months at Jaggars-Chiles- Stovall, a photographic firm that contracts to make maps for the U.S. Army... He starts work only days before the government reveals Russian missiles in Cuba and the crisis explodes.  Oswald may have had access to missile site footage obtained by the U2 planes and works alongside a young man who'd been in the Army Security Agency.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sort of like Benedict Arnold coming back to George Washington's cabinet.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Equally incongruous is Oswald becoming chummy with the White Russian community of Dallas - all rabid anti- Communists.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The Oswalds are introduced by George de Mohrenschildt to Janet and Bill Williams.  It's through Janet Williams in October '63 that Lee gets the warehouse job, right smack on Elm Street at the Book Depository, which is owned by another oilman with ties to defense and military intelligence.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Presumably so he can now exercise his intellect stacking school texts at $1.25 an hour.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: All I can find out about the Williams' is their tax returns are classified and that Bill Williams, a descendant of the Cabots of Massachusetts, has links through his family and United Fruit to the CIA and does classified work for Bell Helicopter which requires a security clearance - so what is Oswald, a defector, doing visiting his wife in his house? Williams has a relationship at Bell with General Walter Dornberger, another one of the Nazis we brought in after the War for our missile program.  He used slave labor to build the V-2 Rockets for Hitler before Bell needed him.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I wonder about the Williams'.  Just where did the first description of Oswald come from at 12:44?  No one knows.  They claimed it was Brennan's, but his description came after 1 P.M.  Who called?  Somehow the FBI's been tapping the Williams' and picks up a call between Bell Helicopter and Janet's phone, an unidentified voice saying "We both know who's responsible."  Who called?  Why's the Bureau been tapping them?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: ...now it gets positively spooky. In January, 1961 - in New Orleans, at the Bolton Ford Dealership - when the Oswald we know is in Russia - there is a man using the name "Oswald" to buy trucks for the Friends of Democratic Cuba.  The salesman never saw him again, but guess who's on the articles of incorporation of the Friends of Democratic Cuba?  Guy Banister.  Banister has someone using the name "Oswald" to buy the trucks.  Hoover, at the FBI, writes a memo dated June, 1960, that there could be someone using Oswald's passport and identity.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Goddamn!  They put Oswald together from Day One!  Like some dummy corporation in the Bahamas - you just move him around a board.  Sent him to Russia, in and out, no passport problems.  You got the word "microdots" in his notebook, you got the Minox camera and the electronic devices they find in his possessions, the sealed DIZ201 personnel file. For all we know, there could be a dozen Oswalds in different cities, countries - all of them leaving a trail of incriminating evidence that could easily be traced to a scapegoat after the assassination.  Does the real Oswald know he's been put together?  Who knows.  It doesn't matter, does it?  He's a low level spy, he doesn't know who he really works for...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't believe it!

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Bugging the District Attorney's office of New Orleans!  It's outrageous!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I think Clinton is a breakthrough. Shaw denies he knows Ferrie or Oswald. Is that right?  It proves he's a liar.  Keep on it, Bill.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: This is interesting - are you ready for this?  Oswald went to see the FBI two weeks before the assassination.  It seems Special Agent Hosty made three routine visits to his house, supposedly to keep an eye on Marina Oswald.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Aren't you being a little hard?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, I don't think I am, Susie.  Anyone else?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: I'm not sure I understand.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well... in an investigation we're conducting your name has come up a number of times.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: I wouldn't imagine where.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We recently talked to a number of men who claim to know you.  Are you acquainted with a David Logan?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No.  Never heard of him.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: A Perry Russo?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: A Willie O'Keefe?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No, I don't believe I know anyone by that name.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mr. O'Keefe told us he met you at the Masquerade Bar down in the Quarter and several evenings later you had him over for dinner at your apartment on Dauphine Street.  Do you recall that?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Perhaps a few more details about the evening will refresh your memory. Mr. O'Keefe told us dinner was served by a uniformed waiter - a colored man.  He particularly remembers that you sat at one end and he at the other - which he found rather unusual because the table was so long.  Does that bring back memories of Willie O'Keefe?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Not at all.  But on the other hand, I do have a lovely Chippendale dining table and I often have a friend over sitting at one end while I sit at the other.  That is precisely the point of a long dining table.  The splendor of the meal adds to the enjoyment of it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I would imagine a uniformed waiter helps.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: It adds a taste of elegance for which I must confess a weakness for now and then.  I call him Smedley.  His real name is Frankie Jenkins - but I could hardly imagine anything more uncouth during dinner than my turning toward the kitchen and hollering "Frankie!" .. Where is this leading to, Mr. Garrison?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: After dinner you paid him to have sex with you.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Pffft!  Absolute nonsense.  The Quarter is filled with vivid imaginations, my dear Mr. Garrison - grimy young hoodlums who'll say and do anything.  As you well know.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: ...in the course of that night, Mr. O'Keefe said a man named David Ferrie stopped by the house... along with another young man...

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: David Ferrie.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No.  I have never known anyone by that name.  Of course never having met Mr. O'Keefe I could hardly have met Mr. Ferrie...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: ...and that the four of you partied early into the morning hours...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Let me show you his picture.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: No.  I'm sure I've never met anyone of such a bizarre appearance.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Does the name Clay Bertrand mean anything to you?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Clay Bertrand?  Clay Bertrand?  I believe there was a man with a name similar to that who worked at the Chamber of Commerce.  Is that the man you had in mind?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, it was not.  Do you know an attorney by the name of Dean Andrews?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: One meets so many attorneys in my business.  No, I don't believe I know Dean Andrews.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mr. Shaw, can you identify this man?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Naturally.  Are you claiming, Mr. Garrison, that Mr. Oswald also had dinner with me?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mr. Shaw, did you ever meet Lee Harvey Oswald?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: You really have me consorting with a cast of sordid characters, don't you, Mr. Garrison.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Please answer the question.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Of course not!  Such a pity, that assassination.  In fact, I admired President Kennedy.  A man with true panache, and a wife with impeccable taste.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mr. Shaw, this is an Italian newspaper article saying you were a member of the Board of Centro Mondo Commerciale in Italy, that this company was a creature of the CIA for the transfer of funds in Italy for illegal political-espionage activities.  It says that this company was expelled from Italy for those activities.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: I'm well aware of this asinine article.  And I am thinking very seriously of suing this rag of a newspaper.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It says that this company has heavily Fascist ties to the French secret army organization that tried to assassinate de Gaulle in 1960.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Nonsense.  What next?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: ...and that this company is linked to the Schlumber tool company here in Houma, Louisiana - which is where their arms may have come from to David Ferrie and his Cubans...

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Mr. Garrison, you're reaching.  I am an international businessman.  The Trade Mart which I founded is America's commercial pipeline to Latin America.  I trade everywhere. I am accused, as are all businessmen, of all things.  I somehow go about my business, make money, help society the best I can and try to promote free trade in this world.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mr. Shaw, have you ever been a contract agent with the Central Intelligence Agency?

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: And if I was, Mr. Garrison... do you think I would be here today... talking to somebody like you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, people like you don't have to, I guess - people like you walk between the raindrops.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: May I go?  Regardless of what you may think of me, Mr. Garrison, I am a patriot first and foremost.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I've spent half my life in the United States military serving and defending this great country, Mr. Shaw, and you're the first person I ever met who considered it an act of patriotism to kill his own president.

turns.speaker: SHAW
turns.text: Now just a minute, sir!  You're way out of line!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: In the sheriff's report, Mrs. Mercer, it says you were at Dealey Plaza two hours before the assassination but that...

turns.speaker: MERCER
turns.text: Yes, it was about 11 in the morning. I was driving west on Elm Street toward the Triple Underpass, in a rented car - a blue Valiant.  I'll never forget that day.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You mean you identified him on Saturday, the day before Ruby shot Oswald?

turns.speaker: MERCER
turns.text: That's right.  When I saw him on TV, I was shocked.  I said to my family, "that was the man I saw in the truck."

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: But you didn't seem nearly so sure in your statement to the Warren Commission.

turns.speaker: MERCER
turns.text: That's what bothers me, Mr. Garrison. You see, they've been altered.  My statements...

turns.speaker: MERCER
turns.text: This says "Mercer could not identify any of the photographs as being identical with the person she had observed slouched over the wheel of a green Ford pickup truck."  That's not true.  I recognized him and I told them so... They also said it was a dark green air conditioning truck, which it was not.  And here...  ...on the Dallas Sheriff's report. This is really strange.  See that notarized signature on the bottom of each page?  That's not my signature. And there never was any notary present during any of my questioning.  I guess that's all...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mrs. Mercer, as a former FBI man, it's difficult to accept this.

turns.speaker: MERCER
turns.text: I know, but Mr. Garrison, the FBI is just not doing their job.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Jim, dinner's just about ready... I've got a surprise for you... tried something new... Jim?  Jim, dinner.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Mmmmm... sure smells good... but Egghead, do you realize Oswald was interrogated for twelve hours after the assassination, with no lawyer present, and nobody recorded a word of it?  I can't believe it.  A police captain with 30 years experience and a crowd of Federal agents just had to know that with no record anything that Oswald said would be inadmissible in court.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Come on now, we'll talk about it at the table, dinner's getting cold.  What are you doing in here?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I can't believe a man as intelligent as Earl Warren ever read what's in those volumes.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Well maybe you're right, Jim.  I'll give you one hour to solve the case... until the kids are in bed.  Then you're mine and Mr. Kennedy can wait 'til morning.  Come on, everybody say goodnight to Daddy.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: One hour, y'hear?  Some Saturday night date you are.  Mama warned me this would happen if I married such a serious man.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh, she did, huh?  When I come up I'll show you how Saturday night got invented.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Honey, you all right?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It's incredible, honey - the whole thing.  A Lieutenant Colonel testifies that Lee Oswald was given a Russian language exam as part of his Marine training only a few months before he defects to the Soviet Union.  A Russian exam!

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I cannot believe this.  It's four- thirty, Jim Garrison.  I have five children are gonna be awake in another hour and ...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Honey, in all my years in the service I never knew a single man who was given a Russian test.  Oswald was a radar operator.  He'd have about as much use for Russian as a cat has for pajamas.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: These books are getting to your mind, Mr. Garrison.  I wish you'd stop readin' them.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And then this Colonel tries to make it sound like nothing.  Oswald did badly on the test, he says.  "He only had two more Russian words right than wrong."  Ha!  That's like me saying Touchdown here...  ...is not very intelligent because I beat him three games out of five the last time we played chess.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Jim, what is going on, for heaven's sake!  You going to stay up all night every night?  For what?  So you'll be the only man in America who read the entire 26 volumes of the Warren Report?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Liz, do I have to spell it out for you?  Lee Oswald was no ordinary soldier.  That was no accident he was in Russia.  He was probably in military intelligence.  That's why he was trained in Russian.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Honey, go back to sleep, please!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Goddammit!  I been sleeping for three years!

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Do you have any evidence against him, Jim?  Clay Shaw's done so much for the city with all that restoration in the Quarter.  He's well connected, all his friends, the money, people, be careful, Jim.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It'll be off the record, honey. I'll bring him in on a Sunday.  A quiet little chat between gentlemen.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Jim, come on, honey, get down on your hands and knees and hunt for Jasper's Easter egg.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You know I don't like these tribal rituals, Freckle Face.  I'm interviewing Clay Shaw this morning.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No.  I told you I was going to talk to Shaw.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: But why in the Lord's name would you do it in the middle of Easter Sunday when you knew we were...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Because when I scheduled it I didn't realize it was a holiday.  You were there, why didn't you say something?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Look at the calendar, for Christ's sake.  You said a Sunday, not Easter Sunday.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'm sorry, but it's important.  Clay Shaw is important.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: You're missing most of your life, Jim, and you don't even know it. The kids are missing out too.  It's not just you making the sacrifice here, honey.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Look, I'll rush and be there by two, I promise.  Go ahead without me.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Tough day.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: My sympathies.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Liz, I'm really sorry.  The meeting went much longer than expected.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: We waited for you... hours, Jim. You could have telephoned, for God's sake.  It's Easter!  You promised, Jim.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't know what to say except I'm sorry.  I just don't have rabbits on my mind.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I think you care more about John Kennedy than your family!  All day long the kids are asking, "Where's Daddy?"  What am I supposed to tell your kids, Jim!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't know what to tell them.  How 'bout the truth - I'm doing my job to make sure they can grow up in a country where justice won't be an arcane, vanished idea they read about in history books, like the dinosaurs or the lost continent of Atlantis.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: That sounds dandy, but it doesn't replace a father and a husband on Easter Day.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It's going to get worse, honey.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Did they live?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: It's not funny, Jim, I'm scared.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Don't be.  Nothing to be scared about, honey, I been through four years of war - this is nothing.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Nothing is going to happen to you. I won't let it.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Leave us ALONE for God's sake!  ...Oh, it's Lou.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Did you enter Virginia into a beauty contest?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: A man just called.  He asked her everything!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Honey, some crackpot.  Martin Luther King was killed in Memphis today!

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Your daughter's life was just threatened!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Just a crank making phone calls. Happens a dozen times a day at the office.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Our home, Jim!  A kidnapper, a murderer, who knows!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Only cowards make crank calls, sweetheart, nothing is going to happen.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: How do you know?  How do you even know what goes on in this house anymore!  You're too busy making speeches, stirring up every crazed Klansman in Louisiana after us!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Get a hold of yourself.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I'm leaving.  I'm taking the kids and I'm leaving!  I won't stand it anymore.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Honey, come on.  The government wants you to be scared.  They want everybody to be scared to speak out.  They count on it.  But there's nothing to be scared of.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: You and your government!  What's the matter with you?  Don't you have any feelings?  Your daughter!  What kind of man are you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I'll take them up to my mother's if it'll make you feel better.  Spend a week.  I'll change the locks, the phone lines, I'll even get a bodyguard, all right?  Elizabeth, get a hold of yourself.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Jim, before this Kennedy thing, nothing mattered to you in this life more than your children.  The other night Jasper tried to show you a drawing.  You didn't even notice he was there.  He came to me bawling his little eyes out.  Jim, he's sensitive - he needs more from you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I promise I'll make more time for Jasper.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Is it such a chore?  I don't understand you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Damn it, if I say I'll spend more time with him, I'll spend more time with him.  I can't fight you and the world too, Liz.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I'm not fighting you, Jim, I'm just trying to reach you.  You've changed.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Of course, I've changed!  My eyes have opened, and once they're open, believe me, what used to look normal seems insane!  And now King.  Don't you think this has something to do with that?  Can't you see?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I don't want to see, goddammit!  I'm tired.  I've had enough!  They say you don't have anything anyway! Everybody in town's talking.  You're ruining this man Shaw's life!  You're attacking him because he's homosexual! Going ahead with this stupid "trial"! Did you ever once stop and consider what he's going through?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's not why I'm attacking him! You don't believe me - all this time you never believed me.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Oh, I don't know anymore!  I believe there was a conspiracy, but not the government.  I just want to raise our children and live a normal life! I want my life back!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well so do I, goddammit!  So do I! I had a life too, y'know - I had a life, too.  But you just can't bury your head in the sand like some ostrich, goddammit, Elizabeth!  It's not just about you - and your well- being and your two cars and your kitchen and your TV and "I'm jes fine honey."  While our kids grow up into a shithole of lies!  Well, I'm not "fine" about that, I'm angry. My life is fucked, Liz!  And yours is, too!  And if you don't want to support me I can understand that but don't you go start making threats of taking the children away.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: You never talked to me this way before, Jim Garrison.  I'm not making any threats.  I'm leaving you.  I'm taking the kids to my mother's.  I am - I am.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: And if you're wrong?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I never doubted for a second that I was.  Will you come to the trial, Elizabeth?

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I don't think so, Jim...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: They killed him, honey.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: He won... and they killed Robert Kennedy.  They shot him down.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Oh no!  No!  I can't believe it.  I can't believe it.  Both of them, both brothers, oh my God!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I want to thank you, Mr. O'Keefe, for this time.

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Call me Willie.  I ain't got nuthin' but time, Mr. Garrison.  Minutes, hours, days, years of'em.  Time just stands still here like a snake sunnin' itself in the road...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: For sexual purposes?

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Well... yeah.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Anything else unusual about him you'd be able to describe in a court of law, Willie?

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: I remember he had some kinda thing wrong with his left leg.  He limped. Don't get me wrong, he's not one of those, you know, limp wrists.  He's a butch John.  You'd meet him on the street, you'd never snap.  You could go fishing with him, play poker with him, you'd never snap in a million years.  So one night we were over at Ferrie's place.  Having a party. Sometime in the late summer of '63.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Willie, are you willing to repeat your statements under sodium pentothal?  Under the supervision of a doctor?

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Fuck, yeah!  I told you so.  And you can tell'em all I told you so.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You realize the things you're saying, Willie, are going to be attacked by a lot of different people.

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: Bring on all the motherfuckers! Bring their college degrees in here! I got nuthin' to hide.  They can't buy me.  You can't buy me.  I don't even need the parole.  This is about the truth coming out.  You're a goddamn liberal, Mr. Garrison, you don't know shit, cause you never been fucked in the ass.  Fascism is here now, Facism is...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No one's trying to buy you, Willie. It's important to know why you're telling us this.

turns.speaker: O'KEEFE
turns.text: You wanna know why?  'Cause that mother fucker Kennedy stole that fuckin' election, that's why!  Nixon was gonna be one of the great Presidents 'til Kennedy wrecked this fuckin' country.  Got niggers all over the fuckin' place asking for their rights, where do you think we got all this fuckin' crime now, 'cause Kennedy promised 'em too damned much. Revolution comin'.  Fascism's coming back.  I tell ya this - the day that Communist sumbitch died was a great day for this country.  I jes' hate to think they're blaming it on some silly fuckin' Oswald who didn't know shit anyway.  People should know why that sumbitch was killed.  'Cause he was a Communist.  Put me on the stand, go ahead, I'll tell the same goddamn story, I'm proud of it, don't matter fuck all to me, things don't change.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: What's wrong, Lou?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Boss, the President's been shot.  In Dallas.  Five minutes ago.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Oh no!... How bad?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: No word yet.  But they think it's in the head.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: One little guy with a cheap rifle - look what he can do.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Let's get outta here, Lou.  I saw too much stuff like this in the war.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I know David - a strange character.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: He's been in trouble before.  Used to be a hot shot pilot for Eastern Airlines, but he got canned after an alleged homosexual incident with a 14-year old boy.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Remember whose office this was back in '63?  531 Lafayette Street.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Yeah, Guy Banister.  Ex-FBI man.  He died couple years ago.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: I'd say he was probably getting intelligence training.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Lou, you were in the Marines.  Who would be running that training?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: The Office of Naval Intelligence.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Take a look across the street.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Post Office.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Upstairs.  In 1963 that was the Office of Naval Intelligence - And just by coincidence, Banister, before he was FBI, was ONI.  What do they say?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: "Once ONI, always ONI"?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Bill, Lou, we're standing in the heart of the United States Government's intelligence community in New Orleans.  That's the FBI there, the CIA, Secret Service, ONI.  Doesn't this seem to you a rather strange place for a Communist to spend his spare time?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: What are you driving at, boss?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We're going back into the case, Lou - the murder of the President.  I want you to take some money from the Fees and Fines Account and go to Dallas - talk to some people.  Bill, I want you to get Oser on the medical, the autopsy, Susan on Oswald and Ruby histories, tax records...

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: They took 'em to the Sheriff's office, not the police station, and they let 'em go.  No record of them ever being questioned.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I can't say that comes as a surprise anymore.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: A photographer from The Dallas Times Herald got some great shots of them never published...

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: ...take a good look, chief, do any of 'em look like the hoboes you remember?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hoboes I knew of old used to sleep in their clothes - these two look pretty young.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: ...not a single frayed collar or cuff, new haircuts, fresh shaves, clean hands - new shoe leather. Look at the ear of the cop... That's a wire.  What's a cop wearing a headset for?  I think they're actors, chief; they're not cops.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Graveyard dead.  August this year.  A single car accident on an empty road in Midlothian, Texas.  The doctor said he was in some kind of strange shock when he died.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We need to find more witnesses, Lou.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: There was Rose Cheramie.  A whore. Two Cubans threw her out of a car on the way to Dallas.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Can we find her?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Graveyard dead near Big Sandy, Texas in '65.  Two in the morning on some highway.  A hit and run.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: I never could figure out why this guy orders a traceable weapon to that post office box when you can go into any store in Texas, give a phony name and walk out with a cheap rifle which can never be traced.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Unless he or someone else wants him to get caught.  Maybe he never ordered the weapon, Lou.  Somebody else did. It was picked up at the post office early morning when Oswald's time sheet shows him clocked in at his job.  Lou, come alive.  These things are not adding up.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Mobbed up all the way.  Tight with the Dallas cops.  I'm digging, chief. I just need 10 more men and some more dollars.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I know you do, Lou.  I'm doing three more lectures this month.  You're all doing an incredible job, Sue, Al, Numa.  But this is one where if you don't nail the other guy, you're dead.  How did Jack Ruby dies so quick?  Of what?  Cancer, right?  A history of Nazi Germany, Lou.  They were studying viral cancers as a weapon in the 30's.  We learned a lot more than you think from the Nazis.  Read this. Our biological warfare lab is in Fort Detrick, Maryland.  Close to where the National Cancer Institute is located.  Think about it.  Think the unthinkable - question everything.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Goddamn Sam!

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: And it ain't pretty  ..."the AD has spent more than $8,000 on unexplained travel and investigative expenses since November, 1966.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: You don't get it, guys - he can't go down any further.  We got to protect him full time.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I have a plane to catch... going to Washington.  An interesting lead, says he's closely connected to these events, but he won't come down here... I know what you're going through with Ferrie, Lou.  We'll talk tomorrow.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: I'm onto Ferrie's Cuban paymaster, Eladio del Valle, in Miami.  I gotta get him in, boss.  I need more men - I can't even pull the teams to watch Ferrie... This is our case!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I took it once for a low thyroid condition...  It raises the metabolism, Lou.  Did David Ferrie strike you as the kind of person who had a low metabolism?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: I'd say the opposite - hypertension.
